importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news release indicates the timing of a significant political purge within China's military leadership, coinciding with the upcoming Central Committee Fourth Plenum, suggesting strategic personnel changes ahead of a key political meeting.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The anti-corruption campaign began in 2023 and has continued into 2025, marking a sustained effort to cleanse senior military and political offices of corruption, with this latest purge being one of the most senior-level actions to date.

keyTakeAways: Two top Chinese military leaders, He Weidong and Miao Hua, have been expelled from the Communist Party and the People’s Liberation Army (PLA) on corruption charges.
He Weidong, the number two general and a former member of the Politburo, is the first sitting general on the Central Military Commission to be expelled since the 1966–1976 Cultural Revolution.
He Weidong and Miao Hua are among several senior officials accused of serious violations of Party discipline and duty-related crimes involving extremely large sums of money.
The purge reflects President Xi Jinping’s ongoing anti-corruption drive, with analysts suggesting it strengthens his control over the Central Military Commission and central political bodies.
The removals are expected to be formalized at the upcoming Central Committee Fourth Plenum, signaling a key moment in political restructuring.

He Weidong and Miao Hua have long ties to President Xi Jinping, having served together in Fujian and Zhejiang provinces in the late 1990s, and He played a key role in military planning around Taiwan after U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taipei in 2022.
The Pentagon noted He’s role in planning live-fire drills around Taiwan, which were among Beijing’s most aggressive actions in recent years.

Other officials named include He Hongjun, Wang Xiubin, Lin Xiangyang, and former political commissars of the PLA Army and Navy; former People’s Armed Police commander Wang Chunning was also removed from the national legislature.
The expulsion of these officials is seen as a signal of the central government’s effort to centralize power and eliminate potential threats to party discipline and national stability.

summaryOfNewsArticle: China’s defense ministry announced the expulsion from the Communist Party and the People’s Liberation Army of two top military officials—He Weidong, the number two general and former Politburo member, and navy admiral Miao Hua, the former top political officer—on corruption charges. This marks the first time a sitting general on the Central Military Commission has been expelled since the Cultural Revolution, signaling a major escalation in the anti-corruption campaign that began in 2023. The actions reflect President Xi Jinping’s broader strategy of cleaning up the military and political elite, with He being particularly significant due to his long-standing ties to Xi and his role in planning military responses to U.S. actions, such as the 2022 visit by Nancy Pelosi to Taiwan. The purges are expected to be finalized at the upcoming Central Committee Fourth Plenum, and the removal of these high-ranking officials strengthens Xi’s control over both party and military leadership.
title: China expels two top generals from Communist Party in anti-corruption crackdown
